entry.title: HID-Attacks-using-Android-Device ü§ñ üëæ
entry.content:
Your Android as Rubber Ducky against targeted Android device or PC

I learned basic Android Hacking when I started my career in CyberSecurity. When I was in college, I attended a seminar about how people can be hacked using their smartphones. The speaker demonstrated a tool called AhMyth (Android Remote Administration Tool), a hacking tool used to create malicious Android apps or APK files. To exploit the victim, this needs to be installed on their phone without their knowledge. It can also be hidden using another app so that the victim doesn‚Äôt realize their device has been compromised.

AhMyth - Screenshots

Official AhMyth Github Repository
Revival of the Original Repository

Since then, I became curious about hacking Android devices. In 2022, I discovered Android HID. Android HID (Human Interface Device) refers to the use of Android devices as HID devices, or the ability for Android devices to interact with other HID-compliant devices.

Android as an HID Device

In this case, Android devices can function as a Human Interface Device. This typically involves using Android as a keyboard, mouse, or joystick that can interface with a host device (such as a computer, tablet, or another Android device) via USB or Bluetooth. This is achieved by using the Android operating system‚Äôs support for HID protocols.

For Example:

  • Android phones or tablets can be used to send keyboard or mouse input to other devices by enabling the HID profile.
  • Android apps can be designed to emulate input devices like keyboards, mice, or game controllers.

How is this used in attacks?

Primarily through malicious USB or Bluetooth connections, where the Android device pretends to be a keyboard, mouse, or other Human Interface Device (HID). This is a form of attack that takes advantage of how these devices are trusted by the operating systems they connect to.

In this article, I will show you how its done.

Prerequisites

  • rooted Android phone with HID kernel support (e.g. NetHunter ROM)
  • OTG cable

Some HID attacks use NetHunter support. However, its usage is too complicated and technical, so in this post, I will show you the simpler method (easy way).

Now let‚Äôs jump with the tutorial.

  1. So, imagine you‚Äôve already installed NetHunter on your Android device successfully. Now, you need to download and install the USB Gadget Tool from GitHub. This application will help enable HID on your Android.
GitHub - tejado/android-usb-gadget: Convert your Android phone to any USB device you like! USB Gadget Tool allows you to create and activate USB device roles, like a mouse or a keyboard. üõ†üõ°üì±
Convert your Android phone to any USB device you like! USB Gadget Tool allows yo...
  1. Open USB Gadget Tool app on your rooted Android phone, this is how it looks by default:

  1. If you look at the bottom ribbon, the Functions section is empty (*). This is because hid.keyboard and hid.mouse are still disabled.

To enable our hid, click the top ribbon. Then you will see the Add Function button.

  1. We need our hid.keyboard and hid.mouse you so enable or add that.

  1. Once you enable the keyboard and mouse you will see at the bottom ribbon, under the functions, that this is already enabled.

  1. Install terminal app on your rooted Android. For this article, I used the Termux terminal.

  1. And you need to login as root by running command su

Prepare your Scripts

We need to create a script to automate attacks on the target device. To do this, you need to be familiar with the victim‚Äôs device navigation. For example, first, the position or location of the browsers like Google Chrome in the device, second, the position of Settings.

This is the script you can refer for the commands needed how you navigate on the device when executing the scripts.

GitHub - anbud/DroidDucky: SImple duckyscript interpreter in Bash.
SImple duckyscript interpreter in Bash. Contribute to anbud/DroidDucky deve...
  1. Transfer the hid-gadget-test and droidducky.sh to your rooter device using adb. You need to used PC.

Run adb push hid-gadget-test /data/local/tmp

Next transfer the bash script you created.
Run adb push your-batch-script.sh /data/local/tmp

  1. And here‚Äôs the script I created for Poc
  1. And here‚Äôs the full video demonstration. This is simple PoC only. But you can create on your own‚Äô like hosting a live malware on your website, then execute it using HID attacks.

Keynotes

USB HID Attack (Rubber Ducky Attack):

An Android device with HID (Human Interface Device) capabilities can impersonate a keyboard when connected to a computer via USB. This allows an attacker to send keystrokes and execute commands on the target system without the user‚Äôs knowledge. The attacker may use this access to perform malicious actions, such as downloading malware, stealing passwords, or gaining remote control of the device. Often, social engineering tactics are used to trick the user into connecting the Android device to the computer, making it appear harmless while hiding its malicious intent.

Conclusion:

In short, Android HID can be used by attackers to manipulate other devices by pretending to be an input device (keyboard, mouse, etc.) and performing unwanted actions, which could lead to data theft or system compromise.

entry.title: New Kali Instance üç•
entry.content:
Automate Installing your Tools in new Kali Environment

There are things that we really can‚Äôt avoid happening while we‚Äôre working, such as the breakdown of something important to us, and it‚Äôs even worse if we don‚Äôt have a backup. As a Security Engineer, I often use Kali Linux on a virtual machine.

Have you ever experienced updating the environment of your Linux machine, or some dependencies and packages, then it suddenly break or have conflicts? I mean, there are times when some programs just become broken and stop working or running.

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to make it a habit to save a snapshot. So, if ever broken packages or dependencies occur while updating, and you can‚Äôt fix it anymore, you can simply revert to the snapshot where everything is still working properly.

But sometimes, we reach a point where we need to install a new Linux machine, where everything is fresh and clean.

Why do we even install a new one when we could just update our existing machine?

Cleaner, Faster Performance

  • Lightweight and Efficient: Linux, especially in its minimal installation form (like using Ubuntu Server, CentOS, or Debian), doesn‚Äôt come with unnecessary bloatware, making it faster and more resource-efficient.
  • Optimized for Performance: It offers high performance in both server and desktop environments, with the ability to fine-tune system resources as needed.
  • No Legacy Issues: Over time, as an operating system is updated, old configuration files, libraries, and outdated dependencies can accumulate. A fresh install provides a clean slate, removing unnecessary legacy files and processes that might slow down your system.

Security

  • Updated Patches: New installations come with the latest security patches, which means your system is up to date with the latest security improvements and bug fixes.
  • No Accumulated Vulnerabilities: Sometimes, when updating an existing system, critical updates may be missed, delayed, or improperly applied. With a clean installation, you ensure that there are no lingering vulnerabilities from old configurations or packages.

Reduced Risk of Conflicts

  • No Shits Dependency Hell: Over time, when you update an existing system, you might encounter issues with package dependencies or incompatible libraries. A fresh install ensures all packages are compatible with each other, with no risk of mismatched versions or broken dependencies.
  • Fewer Package Conflicts: New installations generally don‚Äôt carry over old configuration settings or package conflicts that can arise during updates, especially on systems with custom or third-party software installed.

Updated Software Stack

  • Up-to-Date Software Versions: A new installation will include the latest versions of software and libraries, ensuring you are running the most recent features and improvements. This contrasts with updating an old system, where you might encounter limitations on some outdated packages.
  • Cleaner Software Repositories: Fresh installations pull from up-to-date, clean software repositories, ensuring all installed packages are the latest, unbroken versions. This can avoid issues seen in older systems that might still pull outdated packages from older repositories.
  • Support for Modern Features: A fresh install ensures that your system is configured with the latest versions of essential libraries, tools, and drivers, which might not be available or supported on an older version of the OS.

Simplified Configuration and Customization

  • Better System Partitioning: A new installation offers an opportunity to reconfigure your system‚Äôs partitioning scheme, allowing you to improve disk usage and optimize performance with tools like LVM (Logical Volume Management) or use more advanced filesystems like Btrfs (modern copy on write (COW) file system for Linux).
  • Avoid Legacy Config Issues: When updating an older instance, some configuration files may be left behind, potentially causing problems when newer versions of packages are installed. A clean installation starts with the correct configuration files that are designed for the newest versions of software.

Increased Stability

  • No Leftover Shits Issues: If your existing system has been upgraded over time, it may have accumulated minor issues‚Äîwhether they‚Äôre performance-related, hardware incompatibilities, or small bugs. A fresh install allows you to start from scratch with an optimally configured, stable system.
  • Fewer Risks from Corrupted Update: Updates to existing systems can sometimes fail due to network issues, corrupted files, or other factors. With a new installation, you avoid the potential pitfalls of a failed update.

Installing the tools you use from your old environment to a newly installed Linux can be boring and time-consuming. Also, it‚Äôs like you can‚Äôt remember all the tools you use ‚Äî you only recall them when you actually need to use them.

That‚Äôs why I created a simple bash script that automatically installs the tools from your old machine. This script is quite simple and you can modify it based on your needs.

Scripts Breakdown

this line will check the tools are already installed on the machine:

this line will update your Kali Linux machine

this line will install GoLang

This line will install the tools you need. You can add yours, just follow the instruction:

This script will install GRC (generic colouriser). which acts as a filter, i.e. taking standard input, colourising it and writing to standard output.

and this line will add GRC configuration on your [.bashrc] file

And this line will add symlinks for the tools you installed. Just add yours:

Finally add more configuration in [.bashrc] file:

Heres the full script code:

Don‚Äôt forget to restart your machine after. ;)

entry.title: HackTheBox - Sauna üî•üí•
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí A fun box machine running on Windows with great Active directory on it! The website running on port 80 has given some usernames on abous-us page. I do brute force web directories like I always did on website enumeration but I didn‚Äôt find anything. Running enum4linux I find some useful information that will probably help me to get in. Using GetNPUsers I‚Äôve managed to dump user password hash and I crack it with john and grab the user.txt. In privilege escalation part, I use WinPEAS to get find interesting stuffs like credentials or misconfiguration, and I found a autoLogon credentials. To get the root, the machine is vulnerable to DcSync attack, I get the admin hash with secretsdump and with psexec I login as administrator and finally grab the root.txt.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí visiting the Website looking for possible hint

    ‚Üí found some possible users on about-us page

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí brute force web directories with dirsearch

    ‚Üí enumerate windows box with enum4linux to get some juicy information

    ‚Üí list all the users in a text file with name variation

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí check if the Kerberos pre-authentication required is not set and doing a asreproast attack

    ‚Üí using GetNPUSers i‚Äôve manage to dump the user password hash with his username in it.

    ‚Üí crack the password hash with john

    ‚Üí Login as FSmith with evil-winrm and grab user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí upload WinPEAS and run to find some juicy info that I can use for privile escalation

    ‚Üí I found another credentials that is AutoLogon

    ‚Üí login again as svc_loanmgr user using evil-winrm

    ‚Üí svc_loanmgr has permission on GetchangesAll so we can perform DcSync Attack

    ‚Üí grab administrator password hash with secretsdump

    ‚Üí Login as administrator again using psexec and finally grab the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs a lot of port open. only 3 ports are interesting

  • 80 ‚áí which basically a web service
  • 88 ‚áí which running on Kerberos
  • 5985 ‚áí WinRM

Enumeration

The Sauna Website

Since there‚Äôs web service I always looking that first

In the website I found a possible list of users in about-us page

Post - Exploitation

Enumerationg USERS

I didn‚Äôt find anything in the whole website so I decided to brute force the web directories like I always do in web attacking :

Didn‚Äôt find anything again so I use enum4linux to find some juicy information in the box :

base on the data I got, the machine is running on kerberos and the domain name is EGOTISTICALBANK

I listed all the users that on the about-us page in the website with different name variation :

Exploitation

Kerberos Pre-Authentication

Now that I have users list my next thing to do is to check if the Kerberos pre-authentication required is not set, and do the asreproast attack

I will grab the AS_REP with GetNpUser.py :

Now looking at the result I found that user FSmit is vulnerable to ASREProast and I get his password hash :

Now that I have the hash it‚Äôs time to crack it with john

Grab user.txt

I got the user password Thestrokes23 now it‚Äôs time use evil-winrm and login as FSmith and grab the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

Escalating to svc_loanmgr

upon enumerating the box there‚Äôs another user svc_loanmgr

I need to get the user svc_loanmgr but I don‚Äôt know what to do next so I decided to run WinPEAS. After running I got his AutoLogon credentials in plain text :

so the password is Moneymakestheworldgoround!

We can also get his password with this command reg query HKLM /f password /t REG_SZ /s

Login as svc_loanmanager

So from user FSmith now I will logged in as svc_loanmanager and start enumerating again.

No interesting stuffs found. I decided to use BloodHound to get the structure of all domains :

I just found that user svc_loanmgr has permissions to execute DCSync against the DC

So I can abuse this privileges using secretdumps and extract the hash of the Administrator password :

Now that I got the administrator password hash, we can use psexec to login as administrator :

Grab the root.txt

Now that I‚Äôm the admin i can now get the root.txt

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

ASREProast

GetNPUsers

BloodHound

WinPEAS

secretsdumps

entry.title: HackTheBox - Book üìö üìñ
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí A fun box machine that was vulnerable to sql truncate and local file read via javascript injection. As the attacker I was able to get the admin by bypassing the limit characters of username and password. I created another account to send pdf files which contains javascript payloads which lead to local file read from there I was able to get the SSH keys of the user and use it to get in. To get root access we find logrotten which exploit a race condition and using that we can get a shell as root

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Found login and registration page

    ‚Üí username & password has set limit characters in registration form

    ‚Üí running dirsearch to enumerate potential web directories

    ‚Üí Found admin login page

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí abusing sql truncation vulnerabilities and create account as admin using admin@htb

    ‚Üí go to file upload section that generating pdf files.

    ‚Üí trying to inject malicious javascript payloads to check if is vulnerable to local file read vulnerabilities.

    ‚Üí local file read vulnerabilities confirmed !

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí create a malicious javascript files which can get info of a user which generated into pdf

    ‚Üí extract SSH keys of a user and use it get in to shell

    ‚Üí finally got the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí use pspy to monitor running services

    ‚Üí Looking for exploit for logrotate

    ‚Üí compile logrotate exploit and make a another payload for reverse shell

    ‚Üí execute the exploit with payload

    ‚Üí Finally got the root flag

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs only 2 port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which is running a SSH Client
  • 80 ‚áí which basically a web service

Enumeration

The Book Website

Since there‚Äôs web service I always looking that first

It‚Äôs a login page and there‚Äôs also a create account

I look at the source code and I found something useful, username and password has set to limit characters which can possibly vulnerable to sql truncation

There‚Äôs also Contact us where you can send message in admin@book.htb

Since there‚Äôs no clue what‚Äôs the next step here‚Äô i use dirsearch to bruteforce web directories. This is the best thing to do to get hidden stuff on the site.

So there‚Äôs admin page here. I try to bypass it using basic sql injection but it‚Äôs not working :

Post - Exploitation

Abusing SQL Truncate

remember the registration page that has set limit characters ? The MySQL truncation attack is based on the behaviour of the server when managing special characters like spaces.

In this case if the user send admin@book.htb a the database is going to check if emai are already use by another user. And if not, it is going to cut the username that has max to 20 characters and save a new entry. Because of that I can easily change the admin password. The query is something like this :

and the response was :

We can now stop the burp suite tool. (Do not follow redirect, sometime it will not work)

Using the create account page, I manage to change the password of admin to password admin1234 and now I can use admin account :

Exploitation

Local File Read via PDF

Now that I‚Äôm the admin the most interesting part is the Collections page where you can download pdf file which contains the name of a users or the collections name.

So, as a PDF is being dynamically created for every user, we can control the part of the input. Like performing XSS Attack to generated pdf.

the payload is look like this to get the valid user

next is to download the generated pdf. The pdf contains /etc/passwd info, meaning I confirmed the local file read vulnerabilities

Now we get the valid user reader

Creating javascript payloads

From this article we can perform local file read and try to get SSH keys the payload is look like this :

Now we will try reupload it again :

After that go back to collections and download the generated pdf file.

Opening the pdf it contains the SSH keys of the user

Grab the user flag

Finally I can now login using SSH and the get the user.txt :

Privilege Escalation

Getting Root Access

In our user reader there is a backups folder in the home directory :

then I check what‚Äôs inside on the backup folder :

so there‚Äôs a log file which can be a logs by another user. To monitor the services running on the target machine I use pspy :

If logrotate is running as root, and ordinary users have write access to the log files polled by logrotate, then there is a vulnerability exploit that can increase rights.

I‚Äôve first verify that access.log is a polled file and write 10M random bitstream data to it :

Confirmed ! It‚Äôs written another access.log.2 log file .

Logrotten

I downloaded the logrotate exploit from github to my machine, compile then transfer to book machine :

Compile logrotten

Payload for Reverse Shell

then I create another payload for revershell shell :

Transfer it to target machine using wget and execute it :

Next i check the /etc/bash_completion.d and my payload is written there :

I executed again the exploit and payload and at the same time I setup a ncat listener from my machine. Finally got the root access but‚Äôs it will hangup immediately :

Executed it again and get the root flag

If you liked my writeup please leave a respect on my Profile

Referrences:

Logrotten Exploit

Server Side XSS - Dynamic PDF

Local File Read via XSS

entry.title: HackTheBox - ForwardSlash ‚öîÔ∏è
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí A linux machine which vulnerable to LFI or Directory Traversal which the attacker can enumerate stuffs like file://etc/passwd using php-wrapper. With that method we can get the php-scripts that contains credentials of chiv and get in to machine with SSH. In privilege escalation part I need to get the second user Pain which need some cryptography knowledge to get the passphrase to open his backups file. In root part pain is have sudo privilege to run cryptsetup then I analyze the encrypter.py codes and made a simple script which decrypt the cyphertext then after executing I finally got the magic words for creating backups. from there I got the id_rsa keys of root.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí unning wfuzz to enumerate potential web directories

    ‚Üí Found login and registration page

    ‚Üí Create an account and login

    ‚Üí In profile view we have an option to change profile picture

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí run wfuzz to enumerate subdomains

    ‚Üí run gobuster to enumerate potential web directories and I found config.php

    ‚Üí trying to upload any image and intercept the request

    ‚Üí insert file:///etc/passwd in url parameter‚Äô here we have local file inclusion

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí read config.php via local file read

    ‚Üí run dirsearch to search another web parameters‚Äô and I found dev that has forbidden

    ‚Üí with php-wrapper we can access dev/index.php converted to base64 code

    ‚Üí decode and we can get php scripts that has credentials in it

    ‚Üí login to SSH with user chiv

    ‚Üí Privilege Escalation to get user pain

    ‚Üí finally got the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Analyze the encrypter python file

    ‚Üí make a script to decrypt the cyphertext

    ‚Üí run the backups as have sudo privileges

    ‚Üí mount the folder to mapped images & get rsa keys

    ‚Üí Finally got the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs only 2 port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which is running a SSH Client
  • 80 ‚áí which basically a web service

Enumeration

ForwardSlash Web

Since there‚Äôs web service I always looking that first :

As you can see‚Äô it seems that this website is hacked.

I run wfuzz if i can get subdomains so :

so there is http://backup.forwardslash.htb going on that it‚Äôs a register and login page .

and the sign up page

Create account

To test‚Äô i created my account and I was able to change my profile picture‚Äô one thing I can do with this is to upload an malicious image to gain reverse shell but it will not work on that .

So by uploading image I try to intercept the request and I found a potential vulnerabilities which is the url= parameter.

I tried to input file:///etc/passwd and I can get right response

Next i run gobuster to get another parameters :

Post - Exploitation

Web Enumeration

Exploitation

The hunt continuous

so there is /dev/ which 403 Status meaning it is forbidden or is not allowed & /config.php directory.

I tried to read config.php via local file inclusion and it returns web credentials.

Bypass 403

Next is the /dev directory but we are not allowed to access so I search on google to bypass it and I found this on PayloadAllTheThings about php-wrapper

with that method we can convert it to base64 and decode it .

here is the full base64 code I got :

decode it and I got a php script :

look the most interesting code line is it‚Äôs have credentials :

so the possible userame and password that we can use for SSH is username:chiv & password:N0bodyL1kesBack/

base on the code it use for ftp service but in our nmap scan we don‚Äôt have any ftp services so I tried to use it in SSH

Login via SSH

Privilege Escalation to Pain

Get user PAIN

inside Chiv directory there‚Äôs a note.txt

it tells about the backup file, so I make a way to get pain I use LinEnum.sh

here you can see the backups owned by pain going on that directory

there‚Äôs another note.txt

So the backups may contains the password of our target, to automate the attack I create a simple bash script to get make backups and get the md5sum of that timestamp and get that link and try backup again .

running this :

At first it failed, I tried to run it again and finally :

Get user.txt

Now that i have the password of pain we can now get the user.txt flag :

Privilege Escalation

Cryptography

Inside pain‚Äôs directory there‚Äôs another notes by chiv

I notice that pain can run below the following commands that have sudo privileges without password

let‚Äôs take a look at cyphertext file & and encrypter.py inside pain‚Äôs folder :

Cyphertext

Encrypter

Decrypt

by analyzing this code‚Äô the function applies each character of the key as a mask sequentially for each character of the message. So I created a python script to reverse engineer the code to decrypt the cyphertext

From my Kali I transfer it to target machine and execute :

it takes only a second to get the magic word cB!6%sdH8Lj^@Y*$C2cf :

Next is to go /backup folder which allowed to run sudo privileges :

Now it‚Äôs time to execute it and insert the passphrase cB!6%sdH8Lj^@Y*$C2cf :

Now we need to head towards /dev/mapper To check for mapped images :

inside ./mnt folder there‚Äôs id_rsa

Get the root flag

Finally got now the root.txt

entry.title: HackTheBox - ServMon üëæüíª
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Very nice box which is fit for beginners‚Äô a machine that vulnerable to directory traversal which the attacker can enumerate several files and gain access to this machine. I will say the privilege escalation part is quiet hard if you take the web server of NSClient++ because it‚Äôs takes time to load due high network traffic, but I can easily get the root using cURL to send request. Using cURL i send nc.exe and execute it. Finally got the root.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Service enumeration

    ‚Üí ftp is available so I digging it

    ‚Üí got the confidential.txt

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Login to web page with credentials we got.

    ‚Üí NVMS-1000 was vulnerable to directory-traversal

    ‚Üí enumerate machine with directory-traversal vulnerabilty

    ‚Üí Found the password.txt file on a desktop

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí collect the all the password

    ‚Üí use it bruteforce user using Hydra

    ‚Üí finally I got the right password and login it into ssh and get user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí start enumerating directories

    ‚Üí found the NSClient++ folder

    ‚Üí after searching it on google there was vulnerability in NSClient++ where the low privilege can ability to read the web administator‚Äôs password in cleartext from the configuration file.

    ‚Üí due to high load of network traffic in the web page‚Äô it is so slow to load so I try cURL to get root

    ‚Üí try to put nc.exe using SMB Server

    ‚Üí load the binary and execute

    ‚Üí Finally we get the root

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap Results

So there‚Äôs a lot of ports open but let‚Äôs check which most interesting. Checking that 1 by 1 takes a lot of time

Enumeration

Checking the FTP Service

Since there was an ftp let‚Äôs check it if we can access it anonymously :

Inside the ftp file we got two users ‚Äì Nadine & Nathan let‚Äôs check first Nadine‚Äôs directory and transfer it to my Kali machine.

so inside of nadine directory there a confidential.txt file‚Äô next, check Nathan directory :

There is Notes to do.txt so it is task for our user.

Next‚Äô read the .txt file of two users

so I get a hint from nadine txt file. It seems that the admin put her password in her desktop.

Next the task of nathan :

So another hint I got. the 1 & 2 task are completed but the remaining 3 are not.

Let‚Äôs start digging more :

Post Exploitation

Checking the Web client

I visit on the web page of the box. In nathan notes they mentioned the NVMS, and this seems has version ‚Äì NVMS - 1000.
I search it on google and it is vulnerable to directory - traversal :

The step by step on Exploit DB

OffSec‚Äôs Exploit Database Archive
NVMS 1000 - Directory Traversal.. webapps exploit for Hardware platform

The NVMS login page :

Directory Traversal

In this phase i will try nvms-1000 exploit‚Äô with Burp Suite :

Directory traversal confirmed ! Now‚Äô let‚Äôs try to look at nadine desktop it‚Äôs mentioned on here note that her password is there :

but I got 404 status :

I think password of nadine doesn‚Äôt exist so I tried user nathan if i can get any :

after I send that request I got a list of passwords :

Exploitation

Brute forcing the SSH

I saved all the passwords in a txt file then I create another txt file which contains 2 users ‚Äì nadine & nathan

I use hydra to brute force the SSH service and finally I got the right credentials .

Get user.txt

after I found the right creds. I finally get in to the machine and grab the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

Enumerating directories

at first I started to enumerate the machine directories and I found inside on ‚ÄòProgram Files‚Äô directories what‚Äôs mentioned in nathan's note which is the NSClient++

I search this on google and I found this step by step privilege escalation.

Base on the exploit, When NSClient++ is installed with Web Server enabled, local low privilege users have the ability to read the web administator‚Äôs password in cleartext from the configuration file. From here a user is able to login to the web server and make changes to the configuration file that is normally restricted.

Grab administrator password

I open the NSClient++ directories and try to display the admin password :

Got it ! Now let‚Äôs check on what port is running NSClient++ Web Server

NSClient++ Web Server

Steps to get reverse shell :

I will try to transfer my nc.exe using SMB Server and try to put nc.exe inside so :

I got the message that my script is added. Next i will setup my netcat and execute the binary using this request .

after 1 minute I successfully got admin shell :

Finally I‚Äôve got the root

Grab root flag

After getting the admin I can grab now the root.txt

entry.title: HackTheBox - Nest üïäÔ∏èüê£
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí This machine is really awesome because it has a lot of enumeration especially on SMBClient side. you need a strong knowledge of active directory. Rated as easy machine but other says it is medium box because there is a debugging mode that beginner players have some trouble with it. But unlike other machine‚Äô this one I don‚Äôt have a proper shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Service enumeration

    ‚Üí Enumeration smb shares

    ‚Üí In this phase there was a lot of SMB Enumeration‚Äô different files has discovered inside

    ‚Üí Analyzing the retrived content, some interesting at file RU_Config.xml and config.xml

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Analyze how the decrypting of password works `

    ‚Üí Decrypting the password with `dotnetfiddle

    ‚Üí running the script will give the password for user

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumeration C.Smith user

    ‚Üí Login as C.Smith with SMB

    ‚Üí finally got the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí I initially came across the Debug Mode Password.txt

    ‚Üí HQK Reporting Service v1.2 service running on port 4386

    ‚Üí Enumerate HQK Reporting Service v1.2 with telnet and this will give a lot of informatio

    ‚Üí get and execute the .exe file ‚Äì HqkLdap.exe will give the Administrator password

    ‚Üí Finally get the root.txt flag but with SMB Client

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs only 2 port open.

  • 445 ‚áí which is SMB Client
  • 4386 ‚áí this port is unknow. but in nmap results it has a service of HQK Service

Enumeration

Since TCP/445 is open, we can take a look to see what shares are available:

The Data share seems to be accessible anonymously. We can recursively list the contents of the share with smbclient so :

To easily listed all the directory i use the command recurse on, and as you can see‚Äô there was a potential files which is the Maintenance Alerts.txt and Welcome Email.txt. I download it with smbclient :

Then let‚Äôs read the what‚Äôs the content of .txt file :

Next is the Maintenance Alerts.txt

Then read the content :

Not much interesting so let‚Äôs move another phase.

Enumerating SMB Shares

The Welcome Email.txt give us credentials of TempUser. so I‚Äôll try it to smbclient then let‚Äôs see if gives us any further access to the Data share so :

Looks like we have access to a some files in the IT directory now. I just recursively pull down all the files in the share so :

When I enumerate all the files 1 by 1 on my operating system i found interesting stuff ‚Äì RU_Config.xml and config.xml inside this directory /IT/Configs/RU Scanner/RU_Config.xml

and this the content of xml file I got :

I thought I would use it to try authenticating to the SMB shares but its Authenticaition failed, So i think the password is encrypted‚Äô leading me to suspect that the password needs to be decrypted.

Next the config.xml

Looking at the very bottom of config.xml I see another interesting stuff. Someone was accessing files on the Secure$ share as well as files on the C.Smith user‚Äôs desktop.

Post Exploitation

Enumerate TempUser

so let‚Äôs see if we can access anything in this share as TempUser :

Interesting; it seems that the TempUser doesn‚Äôt have any access to listing the 3 directories. but ultimately I found that the IT\Carl\ folder was indeed listable:

Looks like there is some source code written in Visual Basic. SO I use smbget to recursively download the Secure$\IT\Carl directory for further analysis so :

So this is the whole directory I get :

Looking at the .vb file the Module1.vb was responsible for retrieving the password from RU_config.xml :

And the Utils.vb are responsible for decrypting the password :

Decrypting the Password

We can cut and patch some of this code together to make a single file we can run on dotnetfiddle
I put the hash I got early on the line run the line Return Decrypt script. the decryption is happen here :

Decrypt(‚ÄúHASH‚Äù, ‚ÄúN3st22‚Äù, ‚Äú88552299‚Äù, 2, ‚Äú464R5DFA5DL6LE28‚Äù, 256) so :

from :

to :

Execute this and we will get the password xRxRxPANCAK3SxRxRx this is the final results :

Exploitation

Enumerate C.Smith

So now that I successfully decrypt the password. How about try to login it again in smbclient :

so looks like i can now get the user.txt as you can see on this line :

Grab the user flag

Finally I have now the user.txt i downloaded it using smbclient :

Privilege Escalation

So going to the firs enumeration of C.Smith there‚Äôs a interesting .txt file and executable HqkLdap.exe as you see on this line :

I initially came across the Debug Mode Password.txt file and thought this could be used to authenticate to the DEBUG mode of the HQK Reporting Service v1.2 service running on port 4386 we see this on our nmap scan. The file appeared to have 0 bytes. I spent some time searching around further and couldn‚Äôt find any other files of interest. After wasting some time on futile approaches, I eventually realized that the file could potentially have had alternate streams on an NTFS file system. I enumerated the streams and retrieved the Password stream of the file :

if I run allinfo on it, I can see something else:

So this really interesting it shows password debug : WBQ201953D8w this will be something useful later :

Enumeration with telnet

I‚Äôll connect again to HQK with telnet in port 4386 and start digging. We can then use the password debug to gain the ability to run the SHOWQUERY command on the HQK Reporting Service. This functionality can be used to read files. After spending some time searching around I came across the Ldap.conf file that is located in ../LDAP/.

I set the dir to HQK

I try to show the Ldap.conf and it give us administrator credentials but the password looks like encrypted again .

Analyzing the HqkLdap.exe

I downloaded the HqkLdap.exe and analyze it using JetBrains - dotPeek it is a free NET Decompiler and Assembly

Looking at CR Module binary :

This contains the Arguments that we have to pass in the same script from which we Decrypted the user hash because the hash that we found in LDAP.conf is encrypted using another method which we got in CR module(part) and the arguments that we will pass in the decrypt function and compile it.

Debugging the HqkLdap.exe

Did you rember the vb script that will decrypt the encryped password ? I use it again to decrypt also the admin password hash . I replace only this line :

from

Decrypt(‚ÄúHASH‚Äù, ‚ÄúN3st22‚Äù, ‚Äú88552299‚Äù, 2, ‚Äú464R5DFA5DL6LE28‚Äù, 256)
"fTEzAfYDoz1YzkqhQkH6GQFYKp1XY5hm7bjOP86yYxE=", "N3st22", "88552299", 2, "464R5DFA5DL6LE28", 256

to :

Decrypt(‚ÄúHASH‚Äù, ‚Äú667912‚Äù, ‚Äú1313Rf99‚Äù, 3, ‚Äú1L1SA61493DRV53Z‚Äù, 256)
"yyEq0Uvvhq2uQOcWG8peLoeRQehqip/fKdeG/kjEVb4=", "667912", "1313Rf99", 3, "1L1SA61493DRV53Z", 256

This is the final script

Copy and execute this in dotnetfiddle and we will get the password :

Administrator password :XtH4nkS4Pl4y1nGX

Grabbing the root.txt

Sadly we can‚Äôt use this in Evil-WinRM we don‚Äôt have proper shell to get the root.txt just only smbclient

download the root.txt and finally !

dotPeek - .NET Decompiler and Assembly

entry.title: HackTheBox - Resolute üìü üî•
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Resolute run as medium machine but an easy box‚Äô in the first phase you easily find the users of the box and 1 password by using enum4linux. I run hydra to bruteforce the users using 1 password and easily got right creds with melanie. I use the creds to get with evil-winrm and got the user.txt. The root part was gave me a little bit headache cause‚Äô there was Anti-Virus inside the machine and I always disconnected when I transfer a file like nc.exe or winPEAS.exe for privilege escalation. As my enumeration there was another user ryan which his password is hidden in the directory. Then after I found it‚Äô I switch to ryan from user melanie. When doing enumeration i found that ryan is part of DNSAdmins that I can abuse it by adding malicious DLL in the serverplugin. Using impacket-smbserver i can load my dll file to machine. Restarting the dns service then I will able to execute my dll as administrator.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí run enum4linux gives some usernames and 1 password which can be use that later

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí with Hydra I brute force all the usernames with only 1 password, the password is right belong to melanie

    ‚Üí using Evil-WinRM to login as melanie and got the user.txt

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí enumerating the file directory there was another user ryan

    ‚Üí using ls -hidden we see a file which contains juicy information

    ‚Üí by reading the .txt file I got the password of ryan then switch user.

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí create a malicious dll file with msfvenom

    ‚Üí load my dll file with impacket-smbserver

    ‚Üí running my meterpreter session

    ‚Üí stop and start dns service

    ‚Üí finally I got the administrator and root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

We‚Äôve got a lot of open ports. but the interesting was the port :

445(smb), 53(dns), 88(kerberos) and 5985(WinRM).

Enumeration

Enum4linux

to enumerate some juicy information to box, i use enum4linux so let‚Äôs see :

As you can see here there‚Äôs a lot of users but only 1 password Welcome123! and it use to user marko

as you can see in this line there was a lot of username but only 1 password that belong to marko

Post - Exploitation

Evil-WinRM

I login it with evil-winrm but it failed ! so, i decided to use hydra and save all the usernames on a text file and bruteforce it with only 1 password :

looks easy right ? The password is belong to user melanie now using Evil-WinRM i will try to login it again.

This one of the easiest user part I experienced, now let‚Äôs grab the user.txt then move to privilege escalation.

Exploitation

Transfer file with SAMBA

the enumeration starts again, i try to transfer first winPEAS.exe it is similar to LinEnum.sh for Linux kernel, it helps penetration testers to find some useful info that they can use for privilege escalation so first i setup my smb configuration.

then start service :

now copy the winPEAS.exe with samba

but this one failed me. The machine has a Anti-virus it always disconnect me when I try to transfer a file like nc.exe or winPEAS so let‚Äôs do another thing‚Äô enumerate the directories.

Hidden directories

The PSTranscripts is very interesting because that is not a default file of a windows. so looking inside of that folder :

dir command will not show what‚Äôs really inside of the folder so I use ls -hidden to show the hidden files. and there‚Äôs another folder 20191203

very interesting ! let‚Äôs see what‚Äôs inside of that text file.

looking at this I got another user ryan and his possible password Serv3r4Admin4cc123!

Now from melanie i switch to user ryan and starts the enumeration again.

Privilege Escalation

Abusing DNSAdmins privilege for escalation in Active Directory

Now let‚Äôs start to enumerate it again i checked it with whoami /all

looking at this line‚Äô ryan is part of DNSAdmin Group. This privilege is prone to privilege escation vulnerabilty which allows any user inside this grupo to make the DNS service load an arbitrary DLL correctly constructed.

with this help of this article and this one we can get the administrator from DNS

Creating malicious DLL

we know that the machine‚Äô have anti-virus so I can‚Äôt load a malicious file inside to get a reverse shell. so I tried to use impacket-smbserver to load my dll file from my operating system and bypass the av protection. so first I created a dll file with msfvenom

Next i setup my impacket-smbserver in the path where my dll is loaded .

Setup Impacket-smbserver

next is to load my dll file in the entry serverlevelplugindll in the box :

to make sure that i successfully connect it we can checked it with this command :

Success ! the machine has connected with my operating system as they can view my files to the path where i set my SHARE my impacket-smbserver is also responding.

Now let‚Äôs run metasploit with meterpreter sessions and start listening .

Setup Meterpreter session

all things now are setup. so now I will do the exploitation‚Äô i will load again my dll file.

so based on the article I will stop and start the dns services, this will invoke my dll file and captured meterpreter shell.

then start dns service

and finally got a Administrator shell !

System Information

Get the root.txt

So let‚Äôs pop up a shell and get the root.txt :

entry.title: HackTheBox - OpenAdmin üì¶
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí another easy box machine that you can easily find the exploit and get the shell with RCE or Remote Code Execution if you know how to do with the exploit. The second phase is to find user in mysql database base on the database configuration then login user as Jimmy. user.txt still cannot get on this phase so I need to the first privilege escalation to get the user Joanna by enumerating the website that is running on the machine. Then the root part is very simple. The user has a privilege root to run nano which can execute directly a shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Fuzzing the webpage we get the page music

    ‚Üí Clicking on the login we get the page /ona

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Identifies vulnerabilites

    ‚Üí By clicking the DOWNLOAD button it‚Äôs redirect on OpenNetAdmin with version v18.1.1

    ‚Üí directly to google and search opennetadmin v18.1.1 exploit and it is RCE or Remote Code Execution

    ‚Üí run the bash script to get RCE

    ‚Üí enumerate the shell

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí send php backdoor to get reverse shell

    ‚Üí then run LinEnum to saved time in enumeration

    ‚Üí found interesting configuration files at /opt/ona/www/ directories which the website is installed.

    ‚Üí found a password user for jimmy

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Phase 1

    • get the user joanna
    • we found internal websites which has a running at port 52846
    • running curl with the internal websites I get the rsa key of user joanna
    • decrypt rsa key with ssh2john
    • cracked the rsa hash with john to get the password
    • finally login as user joanna then get the user.txt

    ‚Üí Phase 2

    • running sudo -l the user has given privileges by root to run nano.
    • by referrences from GTFObins I directly execute a shell which is a root
    • then get the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs only 2 port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically a SSH
  • 80 ‚áí which running HTTP Service or a website

Enumeration

OpenAdmin website

as always i first enumerate a machine if it is running a website. Visiting the page I get a default page of Apache

Fuzzing

I tried to run my favorite bruteforce directory tool dirsearch but it takes so much time. So I tried to fuzz the website as my second option withdirectory-list-2.3-medium.txt wordlists so :

I get the directory page music but it seems there‚Äôs no interesting stuffs here :

Post Exploitation

Identify vulnerabilities

if you clicked on Login button it‚Äôs redirect to page /ona which did not appearch on my fuzz.

As you can see it‚Äôs look like a web configuration probably for networks and dns. also the page gave me a hint because if you look the site it is running on a outdate version v18.1.1, I clicked on the download page it is redirect me to OpenNetAdmin site.

So I finally know what to do, directly search to google opennetadmin v18.1.1 exploit and there was on ExploitDB written in bash.

RCE or Remote Code Execution

I run exploit to get the shell of www-data but i have not proper shell :

when I tried to enumate the site‚Äô the only thing i found interesting is the config directory :

trying to list what‚Äôs on the config directory

Enumerate web configuration

I trying first at the config.inc.php and I found a configuration of database file.

when you examine the configuration is database is on /local/config/database_settings.inc.php base on the line :

trying to look at that and I got a password n1nj4W4rri0R! for user :

the problem is‚Äô I don‚Äôt who has the user which I can use on the password I found, so the only thing to do is to get a proper shell then send LinEnum to enumerate all the posibily things to do in privilege escalation.

Exploitation

Get a proper shell

So I set up a netcat listener on my Kali, then curl the php reverse shell on OpenAdmin machine :

Finally I have now a proper shell :

now it‚Äôs time to send LinEnum

running this finally i get now the user it is jimmy and joanna :

i switch first to user jimmy and tried the password I found, and it‚Äôs work !

But still user.txt isn‚Äôt available for this user so I need to escalate joanna, I go back on the /var/www/ directory and there was a internal site which has help me a lot :

Privilege Escalation

Phase 1

base main.php file there‚Äôs a ssh key home directory of joanna. It is prompts the jimmy user to output the rsa key of another user joanna through login authentication. Now we need to know which port this service is running on :

So there‚Äôs a port 52846 running on a localhost i curl the site if i can get the RSA Keys and there is :

I copy the RSA Key on my Kali then decrypt it with ssh2john

after getting the hash now it‚Äôs time cracked it with john

then finally i can login as user joanna with passphrase bloodninjas

and get the user.txt

Phase 2

Going to root is very straight forward running sudo -l we can see that the user Joanna can run as the root user /bin/nano /opt/priv without entering a password.

base on #GTFObins It can be used to break out from restricted environments by spawning an interactive system shell. just run nano then ctrl+R-> ctrl+X then execute a command reset; sh 1>&0 2>&0 then u have finally a shell.

so it‚Äôs time to do exploitation

after executing finally I got the administrator shell root and get the user.txt

get proper shell as root :

OpenNetAdmin RCE at v18.1.1 Exploit

GTFObins - Nano

entry.title: HackTheBox - Mango ü•≠ü•≠
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Another awesome machine ‚Äì "Mango" is a medium difficulty box that was vulnerable into NoSQL injection attack. I was stuck on the main page and the analytics page for an hour until i realize that was only a rabbit hole. There was a login page in staging-order.mango.htb that‚Äôs appeal on my NMAP scan. When I go to the forum I found out that the web apps use MongoDB when you try to search on google Mango db it‚Äôs a database program, classified as a NoSQL database program.
Using payload from PayloadAllTheThings i managed to bypass the login page‚Äô but when I get in i‚Äôll redirect at a Under Plantation page that was another rabbit hole, but it‚Äôs okay because I have now the idea that the machine is vulnerable to NoSQL Injection attack. With my python script i get the credentials for user mango & admin to get in to the machine via SSH and get the user.txt.
In the privilege escalation part there was a vulnerable software installed which is the jjs ‚Äì a java program command-line tool that is used to invoke the Nashorn engine. You can use it to interpret one or several script files, or to run an interactive shell.
I abuse the vulnerabilty by reading the root.txt and also inject my own SSH key and get in to the machine and got the administrator shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Exploring the Analytics page

    ‚Üí check the ssl certicate of the webapps

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Trying to bypass the Login page at staging-order.mango.htb

    ‚Üí with this payload from PayloadAllTheThings - NoSQL Injection Attack I managed to bypass the login

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí bruteforce the credentials of user ‚Äì mango & admin using python script

    ‚Üí After a minutes finally gets the both creds, Login with SSH Key and get the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí execute LinEnum.sh to look what we can do the machine

    ‚Üí look for what permission is allowed to user ‚Äì admin

    ‚Üí found the vulnerable software ‚Äì jjs

    ‚Üí with the help from GTFObins - jjs I can execute File read command to get root.txt

    ‚Üí I can also inject SSH keys with File write command

    ‚Üí Login with my generated SSH keys and become the administrator.

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running a website
  • 443 ‚áí which holding SSL Certificate with "staging-order.mango.htb" I added it to my /etc/hosts file.

Enumeration

Mango Website

Normally i explore first the website‚Äô because that will give us interesting stuffs so :

The main page is looks like a google search right ? At first I didn‚Äôt realize that the main page is a hint for this machine i will tell it later.

Next i clicked on the analytics tabs :

This page is totally a rabbit hole‚Äô I can‚Äôt do anything about the website so I check the SSL Certifcate and it was registed at staging-order.mango.htb so I added it into my /etc/hosts file.

So after that I visited staging-order.mango.htb and it was a Login page.

Post - Exploitation

Bypass Login

I mention about that the main page is looks like a google search‚Äô I realized that was hint to give me idea what should I do for this phase. From the forum it‚Äôs a database, the name MANGO is a big hint, so I go to google and search about Mango DB and it give me a results MongoDB which use NoSQL
database program.

so I search about NoSQL Injection Attack and I found this then tried to login with some credentials and used Burp Suite to intercept the request, then modified the request body parameters base on the payload so :

I modified the username & password parameters by adding this [$ne] sending this it will return to HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Follow redirection and it will go to /home.php

Under Plantation

when I finally bypass the login it goes me to Under Plantation page :

As you can see at the page there was a user ‚Äì admin@mango.htb so I will keep it to my mind.
Now that I‚Äôm in I try to bruteforce the website under /home.php but bruteforcing is not really helpful until I found that this page is a rabbit hole again. but I have got a user admin and also already know that this was vulnerable to NoSQL Injection attack.

Exploitation

NoSQL Injection

I search about MongoDB - NoSQL Injection attack luckily i found this article it is about extracting admin password from the database using NoSQL Injections.

So then I made a python script that will automate the extraction of password similar to the article, this will need patience because password will reveal one by one so :

Get user shell

after almost 10 minutes I complete extracting the user mango password

Now login this with SSH I have now finally the initial shell.

I thought i can now get the user.txt until I remember there was another user that I see on the Under Plantation page the admin user. The next I did is to extract also the password using my python script, I just change only the line ‚Äì username:"mango" to username:"admin" and execute the script.

after 10 minutes the admin password is completed.

now with mango shell I just switch the user and finally get the user.txt :

Privilege Escalation

JJS Exploitation

For privilege escalation phase I will use LinEnum.sh to look for some stuffs that I will use to get the admin shell.

so from my Kali Linux machine, i transfer LinEnum to the target and execute.

As always it will show the basic information of the vulnerable machine.

As you can see jjs is owned also by root, after the script is finish running. I also checked the other SUID :

Get the root.txt

I get a hint from the forum, the privilege escalation part is #GTFObins so I go the website and checked about JJS :

According to #GTFObins, we are able to spawn an interactive shell with elevated permissions, I used File read to catch root.txt at /root/ directory and yes ! I‚Äôm allowed to read that.

I also try the SUID when I execute it my session terminal shell is hang up but I get the administrator shell.

Administrator Shell

I am not satisfy what I did because I want to catch the admin shell and get again the root.txt I have only one options remaining the File write functions.

So my idea is to inject SSH key to /root/.ssh/ directory and login as root with my rsa keys so first i will generate my SSH Keys with commad 'ssh-key -t rsa' then copy the id_rsa.pub and echo it into a file in the /tmp directory so :

And now overwrite the root‚Äôs authorized_keys file :

Now that I setup all‚Äô I‚Äôll login as a root and finally have the last shell and also catch again the root.txt :

entry.title: HackTheBox - Traverxec üóúÔ∏èüìÇ
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí Traverxec is another beginner friendly machine that runs on Linux. The machine has two open ports which is port 22 & 80 that basically running a SSH and HTTP Service. There is nothing to use on the website when I tried to look something but the website‚Äôs has middleware service Nostromo 1.9.6 has a directory traversal bypass that causes RCE or Remote Code Execution and enter into www-data.
After entering the target machine it seems that user directory give us Permission's denied but when I was look at the configuration file we can enter at /public_www/ based on the $HOMEDIRS. The directory contains SSH Key which I use to enter for user david.
The Privilege Escalation part was tricky. As the user has can run journalctl that has root privileges and to get the root is to change the size of our terminal shell into small so I can execute !/bin/bash command and get the administrator shell.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí Search about Nostromo 1.9.6

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerate machine with Nostromo 1.9.6 Exploit

    ‚Üí Metasploit to gain direct access

    ‚Üí run LinEnum or Scripted Local Linux Enumeration & Privilege Escalation Checks to look for interesting inside the machine

    ‚Üí Decrypt the password hash that appear on the script.

    ‚Üí Looking at configuration file we allowed to enter /public_www/

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí copy the backup-ssh-key at the /tmp/ directory

    ‚Üí enumerate david files we see SSH Key

    ‚Üí decrypt SSH Key with ssh2john and decrypt the hash with John

    ‚Üí Login with SSH Key and use the passphrase we decrypt and get the user.txt

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Abuse what the user is allowed to run which is the journalctl

    ‚Üí with GTFObins I see that i can execute a shell with journalctl

    ‚Üí change the terminal into small size and execute !/bin/bash and become root

    ‚Üí Finally get the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí I always begin at NMAP to look on the services what is running. I always use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -A- ‚áí Agressive scan
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running a website also there‚Äôs running a service which is Nostromo at version 1.9.6

Enumeration

Traverxec Website

Since there‚Äôs Web Service running, I will look at it and try what should I got so:

So we have a hint from the front page of the website. I got a user named ‚Äì David White i will take note this because there‚Äôs a possibly that guy we will be our user.

also the website‚Äôs a has a contact form but not much interesting.

other than there‚Äôs no more stuffs on the web‚Äô so I‚Äôll gonna move on the next phase.

In my nmap scan results‚Äô the HTTP Service has running Nostromo 1.9.6 i try to use searchsploit to look if there‚Äôs a vulnerability in that service and yes it has.

Nostromo 1.9.6

It was a directory traversal attack which is lead to Remote Command Execution. I try to look on the exploit with searchsploit again with -x

and the code exploit:

Post - Exploitation

Enumerate Traverxec machine

I search about the Nostromo 1.9.6 vulnerabilities, using the exploit that I have, i can execute a command like whoami and hostname so:

as you can see It give me results ‚Äì www-data. next I try the hostname:

and It gives me result hostname ‚Äì traverxec. Now since I can execute a command i‚Äôll try to use netcat if i can gain reverse shell, but it‚Äôs not working it gives me an error Cmd line: wrong

Use Metasploit to Direct Access

So I try Rapi7 - MetaSploit to direct access in the target machine and obtain remote shell, I search about Nostromo exploit and it is very exact what I needed so :

Now i will use it but first we need to see the options so I can see what is the requirements :

Get in into the machine

So RHOSTS or the target host which is the Traverxec and LHOST or the attackers IP (me) that I will input and do the exploitation.

so I have now direct access to machine. but I need to upgrade it into interactive shell with python :

Finally I have now the www-data :

WWW-DATA

Now that i‚Äôm in, the enumeration start again‚Äô to do this quickly I use LinEnum.sh this script is very useful if the attacker is trying to look what they need to do exploit exploit or use some stuffs for privilege escalation so from my Kali Linux machine I‚Äôll transfer LinEnum.sh in /tmp folder and run it.

And ofcourse running this it will give us a basic information about the target :

and there‚Äôs a previously login and that will be our user named ‚Äì david

I can also see what‚Äôs the user password in /etc/passwd based on david:x:1000:1000:david,,,:/home/david:/bin/bash :

but the script is doing that for me ;)

Now that I have a password hash for david I use john decrypt it with rockyou.txt wordlists. and I got the password Nowonly4me

I try to login into SSH with I password I got but it seems is not the right password. It just a rabbit hole. so moved on try to look again with other stuffs. so I‚Äôll go at home directory it doesn‚Äôt allow me to look into files.

So I‚Äôll try to look more on the machine folder‚Äô I go first at /var/ directory and I see a nostromo which is very interesting.

Looking at the nostromo folder there was a configuration file which is the nhttpd.conf and this will give me a big hint what to do next.

The nhttpd.conf has given instructions :

Exploitation

HOME DIRECTORY

based on the line $HOMEDIRS we can access /public_www at /home/david directory even it is given us permission‚Äôs denied so i go back to the david‚Äôs directory and enter to public_www folder

well there was a protected-file-area and I think it contains data hoping that this one is password but it is a backup-ssh-key not bad ! so :

Well since I dont have permission on that folder to do write I unzip and copy the .tgz file into /tmp directory so :

I see that there was ssh-key files which I can use to get in with user david.

Now what i need is to copy the id_rsa into my machine.

Decrypt SSH Key with ssh2john

I try to login in SSH with id_rsa I thought i can get in into machine but it needs a passphrase‚Äô to get that i decrypt id_rsa with ssh2john to get the hash.

Now that I have the hash it‚Äôs time to use John to decrypt and get the password.

Login with SSH and get user.txt

Looks good ! This enough I think, not it‚Äôs time to login with SSH with passphrase hunter.

Privilege Escalation

JOURNALCTL

This part was tricky the user david is allowed to run with sudo command with journalctl which has privilege unto root, but when I try to run sudo -l it requesting for a password I think that was not the right thing to do. so I search about the journalctl and luckily I found it on GTFObins

It runs in privileged context and may be used to access the file system, escalate or maintain access with elevated privileges if enabled on sudo. so I examined first the file server-stats.head this is a HEAD file which is (another file in the bin directory) and some information about the server.

The last line of server-stats.sh was very important. It runs sudo first, and then journalctl, which means journalctl is running with root privileges. Therefore, if we can control journalctl, we have root privileges. However, we cannot seem to change any parameters. When running anything sudo journalctl -n5 -unostromo.service other than that, a password will be required.

running the server-stats.sh

Get the ADMIN Shell

So this is the tricky part. I need to shrink my terminal size into small in order to execute !/bin/bash command and get the root.
first is I need to run /usr/bin/sudo /usr/bin/journalctl -n5 -unostromo.service which has root privileges, it‚Äôs something like this.

before we execute it I will change my terminal size into small like this.

execute !/bin/bash command and finally I get the root shell and get the root.txt

after you go back the terminal size to normal it look like this.

get the root.txt

nostromo 1.9.6 - Remote Code Execution

Nostromo Directory Traversal Remote Command Execution

entry.title: HackTheBox - Registry üß∞üóÇÔ∏è
entry.content:
Quick Summary

‚Üí My very first Hard box is now retired. A machine where you can exploit if you know what the technology is used. The initial scan has give me a big hint that this machine is using Docker and 3rd party server named REGISTRY Server.
And in the server there‚Äôs a lot container which I downloaded and find an SSH Key to get in to the machine and get the user.txt.
On my Privilege Escalation to the box‚Äô I found out that I need to do lateral movement to the www-data shell which basically the webserver. From that, user can abuse SUDOERS rights by running the Restic and create a backup for root directory to my Kali Linux machine and get the shell and root.txt.

Penetration Testing Methodologies

  1. Network Scanning

    ‚Üí Nmap scan

    ‚Üí discover open ports and what services are running

  2. Enumeration

    ‚Üí Browsing the HTTP Service

    ‚Üí put the commonName in /etc/hosts/ file that appear on the Nmap Scan

    ‚Üí Download and analyze the install file

    ‚Üí Visit the docker.registry.htb and Look for interesting stuff in a Docker API

  3. Post - Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerating the Docker API by following this method

    ‚Üí Found the docker repository that contains image called bolt-image

    ‚Üí Found the some blobs file from latest

    ‚Üí Download all the blob files and try to look for a password or ssh key

    ‚Üí Get in to the Registry machine

  4. Exploitation

    ‚Üí Enumerate the Bolt CMS Website

    ‚Üí using LinPEAS i found a hash that I can use for password of the website

    ‚Üí Looking at configuration I modify the config.yml and upload 2 webshells as fast as I can to gain www-data shell.

  5. Privilege Escalation

    ‚Üí Abuse what www-data allowed to run which is the restic

    ‚Üí create snapshot on my Kali linux machine which will be the backup server for restic

    ‚Üí do reverse SSH in bolt user shell

    ‚Üí run the restic on www-data and backup the root directory that will transfer into my machine.

    ‚Üí get the id_rsa key on ssh folder, and login as root.

    ‚Üí Finally rooted and got the root.txt

Network Scanning

Walkthrough

‚Üí First, I run the NMAP to scan the target and get information about the various services that are running on the target machine. I use

  • -sV ‚áí Probe open ports to determine service/version info
  • -sC ‚áí equivalent to ‚Äîscript=default
  • -T 0-5 ‚áí Set timing template - higher is faster (less accurate)
  • -p- ‚áí Scan all 65535 ports
  • -oN ‚áí to save our scan results to a text file

Nmap results

So there‚Äôs port open.

  • 22 ‚áí which basically use for SSH Connections
  • 80 ‚áí which basically running HTTP Service
  • 443 ‚áí which running also HTTP/S and have ssl-cert ‚Äì commonName=docker.registry.htb, I added that on my hosts file.

Enumeration

So I always visit first the HTTP service because that is a website and I got default page of a Nginx Server.

There‚Äôs no hint for that so i try enumerate the website using dirsearch Web path scanner to look for website page or items which can give me a hints.

Bruteforce Web directories

Get install file

I only got one which is the install when I added it into the URL it is 404 Page Not found.

but I manage to download the install using wget

So I thought this was only ordinary a text file but it‚Äôs not, is a gzip file so I tried to move into a gzip and decompressed but it‚Äôs not working, and I don‚Äôt whats wrong so I move on and go the the next phase.

Explore Docker Registry

Next, i visited the docker.registry.htb and there will be a popup login requesting for username and password, I input admin:admin on that and it‚Äôs displaying a JSON API page.

and the JSON API

Post - Exploitation

Next, I search for Docker api registry exploitation and I didn‚Äôt failed. I found this awesome article which help me to get a password for SSH Key by exploring each blobs file.

So based on the method of the article, I look first at the /v2/_catalog and there‚Äôs a docker repository called "bolt-image" and it is basically a collection of related images.

Diving the Docker Repository

Next I added /tags/list and there was repository install called latest

trying to look at the /manifest/v2

To download the file latest I added simply this in the url /manifest/latest.

Open this file and we will see a lot of blobSum does have the latest repository in a Docker registry. Each of them will contains some info like password, files, ssh key etc.

Here are some blobs from latest.

Exploring the blobSums

So I need to explore each blobSum, i will download each using wget and look for interesting stuffs. so:

Then i will moved it to into .gz file and decompressed it.

Finally i can now read whats is on the first blob.

Base on the first blob i download it looks like the "GkOcz221Ftb3ugog" is a password for SSH Key but I don‚Äôt have the id_rsa which is needed as from this line.

Hunting the Private key

So i need more blobSum to get the id_rsa key, the 2nd blob was empty. and thid blob looks interesting this one is 100 mb total of files so:

Get in into the REGISTRY

after the download finished I explore the /root directory which contains the .ssh directory which has id_rsa and config file.

I look first at the config file and the user for SSH is bolt

and the RSA Key

I move the the id_rsa in my registry directory and do the SSH Login so:

and Finally i can now get the user.txt

Exploitation

So it‚Äôs time to do enumeration again the bolt user shell, I tried LinPEAS to enumerate the shell, then I found out that there was a CMS installed in the machine which is "Bolt CMS"

wget, curl was not working, so I try netcat to transfer the linpeash.sh

Registry Basic Information

BOLT CMS WEBSITE

Going deep of recon I see db.sqlite which contains a password hash, and installed CMS Website at /var/www/html directory.

I visited the bolt website at registry.htb/bolt

Then I decrypt the password hasha using John The Ripper so:

after only 9 seconds i get the password strawberry and login this into Bolt CMS

BOLT CMS LOGIN PAGE

After login it display the dashboard which has a lot of stuffs.

BOLT CMS DASHBOARD PAGE

I search on the bolt cms exploit and I found this article it is the same version on the bolt cms installed on the registry machine.

I tried to follow the exploitation but it doesn‚Äôt work. Also this part was really hard because theres a cron job inside that will erase everything you modified to I need to be fast as much.

So this is the default Config.yml in Bolt CMS Configuration where you can edit accept_file_types.

In the configuration file i‚Äôll put php, and py extensions so I can upload my webshells. Why I need to upload 2 different file ? PHP Reverse Shell is not working so I search for other webshell that I can execute and get remote inside on the webserver.

Until i found out that I can use Bind Shell go gain remote shell. So I created my simple bind shell with python. this is similar to this one

save it ! then I used p0wnyShell so I can run the bind shell (shell.py) and connect it with my Kali Linux so. after done setting up I‚Äô uploaded it into File Management inside the Bolt CMS.

now I will open the p0wnyshell and run the shell.py

You will see that the port is in already in use but it‚Äôs okay I can still connect with my Kali Linux, and Now I‚Äôm on the shell of www-data

Privilege Escalation

As a www-data user we can restic sudo

So as we have privilege for running the restic we can get the root.

RESTIC BACKUP PROGRAM

So what is Restic ?
Restic is a backup program that is fast, efficient and secure. It supports the three major operating systems (Linux, macOS, Windows) and a few smaller ones (FreeBSD, OpenBSD).

Since we have privilege by running restic we can backup the root directory and get the administrator shell.

First I install restic into may Kali Linux.

after the installation, I will create backup folder and set a password on that.

Looking at the backups directories

SETTING UP THE SERVER

Now I will install docker to my machine and start a server at port 8000

Now i will run restic server on my machine and set the path at /backups so:

after it‚Äôs successfully start the server we will go back the the bolt user shell and set reverse SSH so:

CREATING BACKUPS

Looks good ! Now I can create backups in www-data, I will choose to backup /root/ folder because this what I need to ge the administrator so:

Now it‚Äôs successfully saved on snapshot, back into my machine I will restore the backup I created.

Success ! Now it will create /restore folder which contains all the files we need, from there I can get the root.txt

isn‚Äôt enough we need the administrator shell, i will use the id_rsa inside the .ssh so:

GET THE ADMIN SHELL

Docker Registry

Exploiting Docker Registry
